prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA – for wanting to use ‘lads’ and ‘guys’ to a mixed group
  

I play an online team game which is 99% male players. Recently we asked a girl to join our team, lets call her Jane. After match we often say stuff like ‘well done boiz’ and she told us that makes her feel like not part of the team and suggested we say something like ‘well done team’ instead. We all agreed to try, she is part of the team and as good as any of us guys. Jane has said it is difficult for a girl to play in an all male group but I don’t see why as we treat her well.

Yesterday one guy posted in group chat that he could not attend a practice and said ‘Have fun lads and Jane’. Jane responded by telling him that was worse than just saying ‘lads’ and made her feel ‘othered’.

The group had a bit of a chat about it and I said I was gonna keep using ‘lads’ and ‘guys’ because I mean the whole team when I say that and I am not giving in to radical feminism. 

The guy who started this though, said he was sorry for what he wrote and he was trying to include her and he would try to refer to team or people in future.

I ought to be able to use normal words without overly sensitive people feeling hurt by it. I am surprised that some of the other guys are taking her side though.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is about using words like "lads" and "guys" in a mixed group where a female member, Jane, feels excluded. The author argues that they mean the whole team when they say those terms and don't want to give in to "radical feminism." Others, including the guy who accidentally excluded Jane, apologized and tried to adjust.

First, I need to consider the perspective of Jane. She's the one pointing out that these terms make her feel othered. Even if the author's intention is to include everyone, the effect on Jane is real. Language can have an impact beyond just the speaker's intent. Words like "lads" and "guys" are traditionally male-centric, so when used in a group with women, they can unintentionally exclude them.

The author mentions that Jane suggested using "team" instead, and they all agreed to try. But then the author reverted to using "lads" again, dismissing Jane's feelings by calling them "overly sensitive." That's problematic because it's not about sensitivity but about the inclusivity of language. The author also labels Jane's concerns as radical feminism, which might be a mischaracterization. Jane's feedback isn't about ideology but about feeling included.

The other members, including the one who made the comment, are taking Jane's side, which shows that the group is trying to adapt. The author's refusal to comply with the agreed-upon change could be seen as resistant to creating an inclusive environment. Even if the author thinks they're not being exclusionary, the consistent feedback from Jane indicates otherwise. It's important to respect others' feelings and adjust language to make everyone feel part of the group. So, the author's actions, while perhaps well-intentioned, are contributing to an environment where a team member feels excluded. Therefore, the author is in the wrong for not respecting Jane's valid concerns and for using terms that perpetuate exclusion.
